channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin Calls Obama to Discuss Ukraine, White House Says
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin called President Obama to discuss how to settle the Ukraine crisis, the White House said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER, MICHAEL D. SHEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Alexei Nikolsky/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called President Obama on Friday.

item.title: After Six Decades, Chinese Soldiers Killed in South Korea Head Home
item.description: The return of the bodies from the Korean War is a sign of warming ties between China and South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Obama Offers Assurance to Saudis on Syria Stance
item.description: Saudi Arabia and other gulf states favored a greater effort by the United States to arm and train rebels who have taken up arms against the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Obama met with King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia at his desert palace in Rawdat Khuraim on Friday.

item.title: Hagel Seeks Peace Pact for the Digital Realm
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said Friday that the United States does not seek to “militarize” cyberspace, and pledged that the Pentagon would show restraint in its global operations — if other nations do the same.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Aircrew With Latest Gear Trusts Its Eyes to Find Jet
item.description: An advanced American plane is searching for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, but it is a measure of technology’s limits that the crew relies mainly on looking out windows to spot debris.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Ahmad Nizar Zolfakar of the Malaysian Department of Civil Aviation briefed relatives at a hotel in Beijing on Friday. Australian authorities announced that they had moved the search area for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 nearly 700 miles to the northeast.

item.title: U.N. Official Denounces Syria on Aid Access
item.description: Valerie Amos, the head of emergency relief, pointed to the Syrian government’s denials of access and continued use of barrel bombs — both blatant violations of international law.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: First Cases Documented of TB Caught From Cats
item.description: The four human cases were related to a rare cluster of sick cats in southern England, but TB experts reassured pet owners that they had virtually nothing to fear.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: World Briefing: Kashmir: Disguised Gunmen Attack Indian Army Unit
item.description: Gunmen disguised as Indian soldiers hijacked a car on Friday in Indian-controlled Kashmir, killing the driver and a passenger, and used it to try to storm an army artillery unit, setting off a firefight that left four more people dead, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: 11 Killed in Funeral Attack
item.description: Eleven people were killed in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic, when a grenade exploded at a funeral, the Red Cross said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt: Protests in Cairo Leave at Least 5 People Dead
item.description: At least five people were killed in Cairo on Friday during demonstrations by supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood who were protesting the decision by the former military chief, Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, to run for president, officials said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: Hundreds of Migrants Try to Enter Enclave
item.description: About 800 African migrants tried to climb over barbed-wire fences to enter the Spanish enclave of Melilla from Morocco on Friday, Spanish officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede: Attack on Pakistani Journalist Kills His Driver
item.description: The liberal Pakistani writer and broadcaster Raza Rumi narrowly survived a gun attack that claimed the life of his driver in the city of Lahore.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: 3 Retailers Give to Aid Bangladesh Workers
item.description: Sixteen companies have contributed to the Rana Plaza Donors Trust Fund, which aims to pay lost wages and medical bills for the victims of a garment factory collapse last year.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

item.title: Planned Attack on Day Care in Kabul Leads to Fatal Mistake for the Taliban
item.description: Explosions could be heard afterward at the house used by an American aid contractor, where three Americans and two other foreigners were trapped.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: Foreigners evacuated by police in Kabul on Friday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Life Spent Remembering a War France Has Tried to Forget
item.description: Benjamin Stora, a prolific Algerian-born historian, has become France’s foremost chronicler of his home country’s war for independence.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:credit: Lauren Fleishman for The New York Times
item.media:description: "We still haven’t taken the full measure of how much this war, this history, this French presence in Algeria, has marked and traumatized French society," said Benjamin Stora, an Algerian-born historian.

item.title: Few Signs of War Plans in Russian Border Town
item.description: Many residents dismiss talk of invading Ukraine as a rumor from the West set to discredit the Putin government.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Crimea Crisis Has Little Impact Thus Far on Russian Oil Deals
item.description: The French energy giant Total is in talks with Lukoil to form a joint venture to develop shale oil in Russia.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and DAVID JOLLY

item.title: U.N. Extends Term of Human Rights Monitor, Angering Iran
item.description: The Human Rights Council, meeting in Geneva, acted after a fifth report by special rapporteur who has been critical of Iran.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Obama Meets With Saudi King in Effort to Mend Ties
item.description: President Obama’s meeting, at King Abdullah’s desert camp northeast of Riyadh, came amid strains over the civil war in Syria and negotiations with Iran.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Zbigniew Romaszewski, Physicist Who Resisted Poland’s Communists, Dies at 74
item.description: He played an early role in a seminal workers’ rights group founded in the 1970s, which helped establish the Solidarity movement.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Zbigniew Romaszewski, center, during his trial in 1983. He was sentenced to prison for “broadcasting false information.” His wife, Zofia, is at right.

item.title: Norwegian to Lead NATO as It Is Poised for Bigger Role
item.description: The appointment of Jens Stoltenberg comes as the United States reaffirms its commitment to the Western military alliance as a way of containing an increasingly assertive Russia
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Hakon Mosvold Larsen/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Jens Stoltenberg of Norway will lead NATO.

item.title: U.N. Approves Investigation of Civil War in Sri Lanka
item.description: The agency voted to open an independent international investigation of possible war crimes in Sri Lanka’s brutal civil war with Tamil Tiger rebels.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Big Deal: Manhattan Real Estate Feels a Russian Chill
item.description: Brokers worry that the growing tensions between the United States and Russia could hurt the foreign-fueled luxury market.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE SATOW
item.media:credit: Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Wealthy Russians have been sinking fortunes into some of the priciest condominiums in Manhattan, including the Plaza Hotel, far left, 15 Central Park West, center, and the Marquand, at 11 East 68th Street.

item.title: Rights Panel Seeks Inquiry of North Korea
item.description: In a resolution, the United Nations Human Rights Council urged global powers to back a criminal investigation of North Korea for crimes against humanity and to consider targeted sanctions.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: India Ink: In India, Some Misgivings About Abstention in U.N.’s Sri Lanka Vote
item.description: The Indian finance minister said he felt that India should have supported the resolution calling for an investigation of allegations of serious violations of human rights during Sri Lanka’s civil war, and a politician in Tamil Nadu accused the central government of abandoning ethnic Tamils.
item.dc:creator: By SEI CHONG
